results.title: People make papers
results.brief_description: An outstanding film conveying impressions of one day in “The Age” newspaper office in Melbourne. This early film by noted Australian director Fred Schepisi, uses dramatic photography and natural sound to capture the atmosphere of the office, and records all the phases in the production of the paper: the collection of news stories, the lay-out, the printing and the eventual distribution. The camera work is by Peter Purvis.

results.title: People like you
results.brief_description: A recruiting film of general interest, People Like You introduces its audience to members of the Canadian Armed Forces Reserves, who serve as a volunteer force both at home and abroad. They engage in a variety of activities, such as providing civilian rescue services, patrolling the environment, evacuating the sick, and other public assistance functions.

results.title: People into Politics (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The theme of this program is how people in three cities Birmingham, Cracow and Vancouver, become involved in a variety of urban political movements.

results.title: People in red hats
results.creator_credit: Jane Curtis, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jane Curtis reflects on how she spent her childhood sitting in the loungeroom of her grandparents home. As her family spoke in a language she didn’t understand, Curtis was transfixed by the painting that hung on her grandparent’s wall. Only as an adult would she discover the mysteries that painting held. Created as part of an ACMI Digital Storytelling Program in the Digital Studio or outreach program.

results.title: People here really aren't idiots
results.creator_credit: Tristram Miall and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: The work of a halfway house in Sydney, providing accommodation for young people referred from other agencies such as prisons and psychiatric hospitals. The residents stay for approximately a year, find a job, pay rent, and find in the house a stable environment to help them over the acute stages of adjustment, with the opportunity to interact amongst themselves and with outsiders.

results.title: People count
results.creator_credit: Australian Bureau of Statistics and Visual Media
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the 1981 Census and shows how information from the Census can help people make informed decisions about most things that touch their lives. Also explains how the Bureau of Statistics turns the personal details of nearly fifteen million people into purely anonymous statistics. No other credits available.

results.title: People are different
results.brief_description: Made during one term’s evening classes at a London County Council institute. It shows how differently, in learning to paint, people approach the same subject; how differently they handle materials; and how, having gained confidence in themselves, they are able to work effectively on group painting.

results.title: People and power
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein, Peter Pearson, John Kemeny, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film examines Saul Alinsky’s method of organising communities into effective action units based on participatory democracy. Conflict and controversy are an integral part of Alinsky’s approach. Alinsky talks about his philosophy and the dynamics of organisation.

results.title: People along the Mississippi
results.brief_description: The adventures of a toy boat, released at the source of the Mississippi River are used to show the work of the people living along the course of the river and the heritages that these people have brought to America from their former homeland. A French-Canadian boy launches the boat, marked with his name and address. From along the river he receives letters telling of the adventures of this boat: from a Chippewa boy, from Swedish-American towboat captain; from a boy descended from early German migrants, from a girl who is a descended from the pioneers who came west, from a Negro and white boy on the cotton land of the South and from a girl living on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico.
